description: Borrowed from Middle French notice, from the Latin nōtitia.

entries.meaning: (chiefly uncountable) The act of observing; perception.
examples: He took no notice of the changes, and went on as though nothing had happened.
Shall we post a notice about the new policy?
I always read the death notices in the paper.
The sidewalk adjacent to the damaged bridge stonework shall be closed until further notice.

entries.meaning: (chiefly uncountable) Advance notification of termination of employment, given by an employer to an employee or vice versa.
examples: I gave her her mandatory two weeks' notice and sacked her.
I can't work here any longer. I'm giving notice.

entries.meaning: (countable) A published critical review of a play or the like.
examples: The first-night audience, yes. The first-night reviewers, not exactly. The notices have so far been mixed, only The Financial Times having delivered itself of an unequivocal rave.
I don't mind if you want to change the venue; just give me some notice first, OK?

verbs.description: notice (third-person singular simple present notices, present participle noticing, simple past and past participle noticed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, now rare) To remark upon; to mention. [from 17th c.]
(transitive) To become aware of; to observe. [from 17th c.]
examples: So you punched out a window for ventilation. Was that before or after you noticed you were standing in a lake of gasoline?

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To lavish attention upon; to treat (someone) favourably. [17th–19th c.]
(intransitive) To be noticeable; to show. [from 20th c.]
examples: The blackness didn't notice so much when she was born; but it's unmistakeable now.
